You recall that a magnifying lens is used for enlarging small objects. Figure 2.1 shows a hand lens. In order to use the hand lens to magnify an object, place the object on the bench and move the hand lens from the object towards the eye until an enlarged image is seen. If a hand lens is used to make a drawing, the lens magnification does not determine the drawing’s magnification. Drawing magnification = length of the drawing ÷ length of the object. Figure 2.2 shows how this formula is applied.

Before defining classification, review the organisms collected in activities 1 and 2 and compare with those shown in figure 2.3 to appreciate why classification is necessary.

Classification is the grouping of living organisms according to structure and evolutionary relationships (phylogeny). A group is a taxon (plural: taxa). The science of classification is taxonomy; its practitioners are taxonomists.

Why classification is necessary: • Correct identification and referencing • Groups organisms with similar characteristics, separates those with different features • Arranges biological information orderly • Helps us understand evolutionary relationships between organisms.

Historically, artificial classification used few observable traits (e.g., Aristotle). Modern classification uses evolutionary relationships from common ancestry. Carolus Linnaeus (1707–1778) pioneered modern classification. (Figure 2.3 illustrates organismal diversity.)

Taxonomic hierarchy and five kingdoms. Kingdom → Phylum/Division → Class → Order → Family → Genus → Species. Five kingdoms: Monera (bacteria), Protoctista (algae, protozoa), Fungi (moulds, yeasts, mushrooms), Plantae (mosses, ferns, maize, pea, pine, Meru oak), Animalia (hydra, tapeworms, bees, humans). As we go down the hierarchy, groups contain fewer organisms but with greater similarity. A species is the smallest unit; members interbreed to produce fertile offspring. Subspecific variation (varieties, races, strains) may be recognised.

Binomial nomenclature (Linnaeus, 18th c.) uses Latinised genus + species names (e.g., Homo sapiens, Zea mays). Rules: genus capitalised, species lower-case; italicised in print (underlined when handwritten); sometimes includes the describing scientist (e.g., Balanus balanoides Linnaeus). Reasons for Latin: universality and clarity across local languages. Practical Activity: Naming organisms using local/English/scientific names; sources for verification (teacher, texts, museums, herbarium, research institutes).

Cells are the basic units of life. Some organisms are unicellular (e.g., amoeba); others are multicellular (e.g., pea, cow). History of microscopy: Jansen (c.1650) compound microscope; Hooke (1665) observed cells; Leeuwenhoek (1650–1700) improved magnification and observed nuclei/bacteria; 1930s electron microscope revealed internal cell structures.

The light microscope (uses light for illumination) reveals fine details not visible to the eye or hand lens. Know its parts, care and use (see fig. 3.1 and table 3.1). Handle carefully; it is delicate and expensive.

Parts and functions of a light microscope and safe handling rules; step-by-step procedure to focus under low/medium/high power; compute total magnification = eye-piece × objective. Practical Activity: identify parts, draw and label, calculate magnification.

Cell structures visible under the light microscope: in plants—cell wall, cell membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus, vacuole, chloroplasts; in animals—cell membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus, small vacuoles. Organelles perform specific functions.
Electron microscope magnifies up to ~500,000× with high resolving power; uses electrons instead of light. Reveals ultrastructure (e.g., membranes, organelles).

Overview of cell ultrastructure and organelles: membrane (trilaminar lipoprotein; selectively permeable), cytoplasm (site of reactions; streaming; inclusions), mitochondria (cristae; sites of respiration), endoplasmic reticulum (rough with ribosomes → protein transport; smooth → lipid transport), ribosomes (protein synthesis), lysosomes (lytic enzymes), Golgi apparatus (packaging/secretion), centrioles (cell division; absent in plants), chloroplasts (photosynthesis; grana), vacuoles (cell sap; storage; turgor), cell wall (cellulose; support; fully permeable), nucleus (membrane with pores; nucleoplasm; nucleolus; chromatin; control center). Include comparisons of plant vs animal cells.

Preparing and observing temporary slides (onion epidermis): apparatus, steps to make wet mount and stained mount; estimating field of view diameter with a ruler; calculating cell size from field of view and count. Differences between plant and animal cells (Table 3.3).

Estimating cell size: unit conversions (mm ↔ μm ↔ nm); count cells across field of view; Cell Diameter = (Diameter of field of view in μm) ÷ (number of cells across). Study Question: limitations of the method; other useful dimensions for irregular cells.

Cell physiology studies the functions of cell structures (photosynthesis in chloroplasts; respiration in mitochondria; protein synthesis in ribosomes). Substances continuously move across membranes for these processes; we discuss diffusion, osmosis, and active transport.

Membranes (cell, tonoplast, nuclear, mitochondrial, chloroplast) share a basic structure that regulates material movement. The cell membrane is a lipoprotein trilayer (~7.5 nm) with pores allowing selective passage.
Properties of the cell membrane: semi-permeability; sensitivity to temperature and pH (proteins denature); electric charges influencing transport and environmental sensing. Study Questions included.

Introduction to diffusion, osmosis, active transport. Practical Activity: demonstrate diffusion with potassium manganate (VII); definition and roles of diffusion (absorption, gaseous exchange, excretion, translocation). Factors affecting diffusion: gradient, surface area to volume ratio, thickness, molecule size, temperature.
Osmosis demo with visking tubing: setup, observations, interpretation (semi-permeable membrane allows water, not large solutes).

Definition of osmosis; isotonic/hypotonic/hypertonic solutions; osmosis as a special diffusion across semi-permeable membrane. Practical: osmosis in potato tissue; osmotic pressure and potential; water relations in animals (haemolysis, crenation).

Water relations in plant cells: turgor and wall pressure; plasmolysis and deplasmolysis; practical with onion epidermis; wilting vs permanent wilting; roles of osmosis (absorption, support, stomatal opening, insectivorous plants, osmoregulation).

Active transport moves substances against gradients using energy; carrier-mediated uptake. Roles: kidney reabsorption, mineral uptake by roots, absorption from gut, osmotic balance, excretion. Factors affecting active transport: O2, pH, glucose, inhibitors, temperature.

Nutrition introduction: food is required for energy, growth and repair. Modes include autotrophism (self-manufacture of food e.g. photosynthesis, chemosynthesis) and heterotrophism (consuming complex foods from plants or animals).

Photosynthesis: external and internal leaf structure, cuticle, epidermis, guard cells, palisade and spongy mesophyll, veins. Adaptations for photosynthesis (large lamina, thinness, stomata, chloroplasts, vascular bundles, leaf mosaic). Chloroplast structure (double membrane, grana, stroma, chlorophyll). Light and dark stages: photolysis, ATP formation, carbon fixation. Practical activities: starch test in leaves, factors affecting photosynthesis (light, CO₂, temperature, water).

Biochemistry of food: carbohydrates (mono-, di-, polysaccharides), tests for starch and sugars; lipids (fats, oils; properties; Sudan test, emulsion test); proteins (amino acids, peptide bonds, denaturation, tests for protein); enzymes (naming, properties, factors affecting activity, inhibitors, co-factors, importance).

Heterotrophism: holozoic, saprophytic, parasitic, symbiotic nutrition. Human dentition and types of teeth (incisors, canines, premolars, molars), adaptations in herbivores, carnivores, omnivores. Structure of a tooth. Dental diseases and hygiene. Digestive system structure and functions. Digestive processes in mouth, stomach, duodenum, ileum. Emulsification, enzyme action, absorption in ileum (villi, lacteals), assimilation. Egestion and role of caecum/appendix. Practical activities: emulsification, digestion experiments.
Detailed digestion processes and assimilation. Summary of enzyme actions in digestion. Conditions when proteins are used as energy source. Practical dissection of mammal digestive system.

Vitamins and mineral salts: sources, roles, deficiency diseases (e.g., Vitamin C → scurvy, Vitamin D → rickets, Vitamin A → night blindness). Practical activity: test for Vitamin C with DCPIP. Roughage and water roles in digestion.
Energy values of foods; factors influencing energy requirements (BMR, activity, age, body size, sex). Table 5.4: daily energy use in males vs females.
